brief_summary.textblock:
The objective of the study is to evaluate the reliability of the impedance data in adult
      subjects measured with five different FOT devices.

clinical_study.brief_title: Reliability of Different FOT Devices to Measure the Human Respiratory Impedance

detailed_description.textblock:
The purpose of the study is to evaluate the reliability of the respiratory impedance
      measured with different FOT (=Forced Oscillation Technique) devices. To this end, the
      respiratory impedance of fifty adult subjects will be measured in random order with five
      different forced oscillation devices. As there is no "gold standard" FOT-device, each setup
      will be compared to all other setups.

      Secondary study questions are: 1) is there a specific comfort (or discomfort) associated
      with the different measuring devices 2) Guidelines state that full chin and cheek support
      should be applied when measuring the human respiratory impedance. What is the influence of a
      partial cheek support?

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Healthy adult subjects

          -  Adult patients with obstructive lung disease

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Inability to perform lung function tests

          -  Patients with respiratory failure

          -  Patients on BIPAP-therapy

          -  Patients on supplemental oxygen.

study_pop.textblock: Healthy adult subjects and patients with obstructibve lung disease

facility.name: Dept. of Pulmonary Medicine, Antwerp University Hospital

clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of the Reliability of Different Devices to Measure Lung Function With the Forced Oscillation Technique

other_outcome.description: The effect of two modes of cheek support on the Zrs-estimate will be assessed in each investigated subject with one (randomly chosen) FOT-device.
other_outcome.measure: Effect of the mode of cheek support on the Zrs-measurement

primary_outcome.description: Bland-Altman plot of Zrs measured with two devices
primary_outcome.measure: Comparison of the respiratory impedance measured with two different FOT devices

reference.citation: Oostveen E, MacLeod D, Lorino H, Farré R, Hantos Z, Desager K, Marchal F; ERS Task Force on Respiratory Impedance Measurements. The forced oscillation technique in clinical practice: methodology, recommendations and future developments. Eur Respir J. 2003 Dec;22(6):1026-41. Review.

Oostveen E, Boda K, van der Grinten CP, James AL, Young S, Nieland H, Hantos Z. Respiratory impedance in healthy subjects: baseline values and bronchodilator response. Eur Respir J. 2013 Apr 18. [Epub ahead of print]
Bland JM, Altman DG. Statistical methods for assessing agreement between two methods of clinical measurement. Lancet. 1986 Feb 8;1(8476):307-10.

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Rating of the subjective experience of the Zrs-measurement with a specific FOT device
secondary_outcome.measure: Subjective evaluation of the Zrs-measurement with a specific FOT device by the investigated subject.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Cross-Sectional
